qas.question: Hokkien is usually written using what characters?
Written Hokkein is based on what?
What is another name for standard written chinese?
Approximately what percentage of Chinese morphemes lack a standard chinese character?
What percentage of written Chinese lacks a standard Chinese character?
What is used for Mandarin but doesn't correspond to Taiwanese words?
What is written Cantonese based on?
What is adapted to the spoken form of Chinese?

context: Hokkien dialects are typically written <b5_0>using <a0_0>Chinese<a0_0/> characters<b5_0/> (漢字, Hàn-jī). However, <b8_0>the written script<b8_0/> was and remains adapted to the literary form, which is based on <a1_0><b7_0>classical Chinese<b7_0/><a1_0/>, not the vernacular and spoken form. Furthermore, <b6_0>the character inventory<b6_0/> used for <a2_0>Mandarin<a2_0/> (standard written Chinese) does not correspond to Hokkien words, and there are a large number of informal characters (替字, thè-jī or thòe-jī; 'substitute characters') which are unique to Hokkien (as is the case with Cantonese). For instance, <b4_0>about <a3_0>20 to 25%<b4_0/><a3_0/> of Taiwanese morphemes lack an appropriate or standard Chinese character.
